awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Multi-omic Analyses and Dynamic Modeling to Understand Fungal Cell-wall Stress Responses
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative Research: Using multi-omic analyses and dynamic modeling to understand fungal cell-wall stress responses

This project will develop a better understanding of how the model filamentous fungus, Aspergillus nidulans, repairs its cell wall during periods of stress. This understanding is important for society as beneficial species of filamentous fungi are used to produce billions of dollars of commercial products annually, while pathogenic species are responsible for billions of dollars in crop damage and are a significant threat to human health. In both beneficial and pathogenic species of fungi, the cell wall plays a critical role enabling the fungus to grow and survive in diverse environments. To help understand the fungal response to stress, sophisticated mathematical models will be developed to describe system behavior and these models have the potential to extend to other biological systems. This research will also have a broad impact on human capital, as it has a significant educational component. In the three different laboratories involved, work will include both graduate and undergraduate students. The plan also includes outreach to underrepresented minorities through the UMBC Meyerhof Scholars program. These robust and interdisciplinary training opportunities will contribute to the development of a diverse STEM workforce.

While the ability to respond to cell wall stress is a critical feature of growth and morphogenesis in filamentous fungi, the different regulatory modules that underlie this response are not well understood.  We seek to determine how three specific regulatory modules interact to mediate the response to cell wall stress. To do this, we use phosphoproteomic analysis to reveal kinase-mediated regulatory behavior and transcriptomic analysis to reveal stress-associated changes in gene expression. An important aspect of the proposed work is that dynamic data will be gathered to understand how phosphosite occupancy and gene expression change with time. In addition to experiments, we will use a novel mathematical modeling approach to build a robust kinetic model (set of coupled ordinary differential equations) describing wall stress response. A key feature of the modeling is that in addition to gene expression values, a critical variable will be phosphosite occupancy. We note there are often multiple phosphosites on a single protein and that these are often the substrates of different protein kinases. Our model will help us make connections in this complex network. To develop the model, we will use a Design-Build-Test-Learn approach, wherein the model is used to make network predictions which are then tested experimentally. The data from these experiments will then be used to improve the model. This will allow us to evolve the model to accurately represent system behavior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research has advanced scientific understanding of how fungi respond to cell wall stress while developing new computational tools that benefit multiple fields of study. This work combines detailed biological investigation with innovative mathematical approaches to address both fundamental questions about fungal biology and practical challenges in medicine and materials science.


The intellectual contributions of this project include several significant discoveries about fungal biology. Using the model organism Aspergillus nidulans, we revealed that internal cellular barriers called septa are essential for surviving cell wall damage, providing new insights into fungal stress resistance mechanisms. We also discovered that the protein BrlA, previously known only for controlling spore formation, plays a direct role in regulating genes involved in cell wall stress response. Through genome-wide analysis, we identified 332 genes containing BrlA response elements, with 28 showing specific activity during wall stress. This finding reveals new connections between fungal stress responses and development, expanding our understanding of how fungi coordinate these essential processes.


Our project also made important methodological advances. We developed novel computational approaches, including a Derivative Profiling method that efficiently identifies significant changes in gene activity over time and an artificial intelligence system that can accurately predict gene expression patterns from minimal experimental data. These tools represent significant innovations in biological data analysis, making it possible to extract meaningful insights from complex experimental data more effectively than previous methods.


The broader impacts of our work contribute to several areas. In medicine, our findings about fungal stress responses provide additional insights that may assist in antifungal drug development. In materials science, we developed computational methods for designing fungal-based materials, contributing to ongoing efforts to develop sustainable alternatives to conventional materials. While these applications require further development, they demonstrate promising directions for future research and development.


The project has provided valuable interdisciplinary training for graduate students in both experimental biology and computational analysis. This training combines traditional laboratory techniques with modern computational methods, preparing students for careers in contemporary biological research. Our findings have been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, facilitating knowledge sharing within the scientific community.


Beyond specific applications, our work demonstrates the value of combining biological experimentation with computational innovation. The mathematical tools we developed can potentially be adapted to study other biological systems, extending the impact beyond fungal biology. Our approaches to designing fungal-based materials could also inform similar methods in other areas of sustainable materials development.


This research exemplifies how modern scientific investigation can advance fundamental understanding while exploring practical applications. By bridging multiple disciplines and combining experimental and computational approaches, we have expanded scientific knowledge while developing tools that may help address challenges in human health, environmental sustainability, and technological innovation.
